metadata.purpose: AI Agent Training - YouTube Content Generation & Classification

pillar_1_curiosity_gap.name: The Click
pillar_1_curiosity_gap.description: Title and thumbnail combination engineering an insurmountable gap between what the viewer knows and what they need to know

pillar_2_narrative_hook.name: The Pledge
pillar_2_narrative_hook.description: Opening moments must utilize Cold Open Payoff or Montage of Failure to establish credibility. Viewer must believe creator has already achieved the feat before narrative begins

pillar_3_mid_video_pivot.name: The Turn
pillar_3_mid_video_pivot.description: Calculated narrative shift—new obstacle, rule change, or tonal pivot—that resets viewer attention span past the 8-minute monetization threshold

retention_rules.3_second_rule: 50-60% of drop-offs occur in first 3 seconds. Thumbnail promise must be delivered immediately.
retention_rules.8_minute_threshold: Critical mark for mid-roll ad monetization and deeper algorithmic signaling
retention_rules.conclusion_preview: Hinting at verdict in first minute increases watch completion by 15-25%
retention_rules.turn_cluster: Narrative pivots cluster at 50-70% mark across all archetypes

faceless_adaptability.notes: Requires on-camera presence, large budgets, real-world logistics. Not suitable for faceless/AI generation.

top_creators.name: MrBeast
top_creators.role: Primary innovator and industrializer of format

psychological_mechanics.explanation: Stakes must rise exponentially. Linear narrative insufficient—if video begins with $10K challenge, must conclude with $100K. Variable rewards (prizes, twists, eliminations) feed anticipation loop like slot machine. Viewer watches not just to see winner but to witness chaotic variables influencing outcome.

rules: Use specific numerical precision (not 'cheap vs expensive')
Extreme contrast required (6+ orders of magnitude difference)
Object must be aspirational but relatable
examples: I Spent 50 Hours In Solitary Confinement
Last To Leave Circle Wins $500,000
I Survived 100 Days In A Circle

thumbnail_meta.face_expression: Screaming/Shocked—exaggerated reaction with wide eyes, open mouth
thumbnail_meta.composition: Creator's face (70% of frame) + Prize/danger clearly visible
thumbnail_meta.text_overlays: Minimal but bold—price contrast or stakes in clean sans-serif

structure.instruction: Show the climax immediately (explosion, cash, winner screaming) to prove payoff exists
structure.example_script: [DRONE SHOT of $1M yacht] 'I rented a million-dollar-a-night yacht!'

structure.instruction: Rapid-fire explanation of challenge mechanics
structure.example_script: 'If he touches the red line, he loses everything. If she steps outside the circle, she's eliminated.'
structure.purpose: Set up game mechanics, create investment in outcome

structure.instruction: State the prize and consequences clearly
structure.example_script: 'Last one standing wins $500,000. But there's a twist none of them know about.'

structure.instruction: Challenge begins immediately. NO intro sequence or channel branding. Cover multiple milestones quickly (Crazy Progression technique)
structure.example_script: [MONTAGE] Day 1, Day 3, Day 7—rapid cuts showing deteriorating conditions

cut_speed.description: Hyper-fast. Zero tolerance for dead air or pauses.

b_roll_patterns: Quick montage of features during tours
Jump cuts to remove all filler

music_and_sound.music_style: Orchestral tension loops, high-energy Epidemic Sound tracks
music_and_sound.sound_effects: Whoosh on every transition, hits and risers punctuating cuts, cash register sounds for money reveals
music_and_sound.technique: Sound effects are structural, not decorative. Silence momentarily before big reveals for contrast.

visual_effects: Large colorful subtitles ('Beast Text') for accessibility
Glows and arrows highlighting key objects
retention_editing_rules: Never show winner until final segment

turn_types.name: Rule Change
turn_types.description: Just as viewers get comfortable, the rules change
turn_types.example: 'But I didn't tell them about the surprise—if they touch the walls, they lose half their money'

turn_types.name: Celebrity Surprise
turn_types.description: Unexpected cameo broadens reach to new audiences
turn_types.example: Famous YouTuber or athlete joins halfway through

turn_types.name: Stakes Doubling
turn_types.description: Prize or consequences suddenly increase
turn_types.example: 'The prize just went from $100K to $500K'

turn_types.name: Elimination Twist
turn_types.description: Eliminated players get second chance or return
turn_types.example: 'Everyone you voted out is coming back'

the_turn.tension_mechanics: Investment in specific contestants; winner uncertainty until end; physical/emotional stakes visible on screen

algorithmic_implications.shareability: Very High—spectacle nature drives social sharing

faceless_adaptability.notes: Requires real contestants, physical challenges, extended filming. Impossible to create without human participants.

psychological_mechanics.explanation: Combines reality TV elimination drama with YouTube creator personality. Viewers pick favorites and root for their survival. Investment deepens as field narrows. The 'who will win?' mystery drives full watch completion.

rules: Clear stakes in title (prize amount or survival duration)
Location or condition must sound difficult/extreme
examples: Last To Leave Circle Wins $500,000
I Survived 100 Days In A Circle
I Spent 50 Hours Buried Alive
100 Players Compete for $1,000,000

thumbnail_meta.composition: Subject clearly in challenge environment (person in circle, in box, extreme location)
thumbnail_meta.color_scheme: Darker/more dramatic than comparison videos; spotlight on subject against dark background
thumbnail_meta.text_overlays: Time stamp ('DAY 50'), prize amount ('$500,000'), or countdown element

structure.instruction: Spectacular visual establishing production scale
structure.example_script: [CRANE SHOT] House being lowered into position by crane
structure.purpose: Establish 'who else on YouTube can do this?'

structure.instruction: Simple, clear game mechanics
structure.example_script: 'If you can stay in this circle for 100 days, you win $500,000. Step outside, you're eliminated.'

structure.instruction: Flash names and brief personality hints
structure.example_script: [QUICK CUTS] 'This is Marcus, a former Marine. Sarah, a single mom. Jake, who's never won anything.'

structure.instruction: Cover multiple days in 15 seconds—don't dwell on Day 1
structure.example_script: [MONTAGE] Day 1... Day 7... Day 15... conditions deteriorating
structure.purpose: Fast forward through setup, show stakes rising

structure.instruction: Show someone quitting or breaking down
structure.example_script: [EMOTIONAL] 'I can't do this anymore...' [CUT TO] Someone stepping out of circle

structure.instruction: Show silhouettes of remaining contestants, hint at drama
structure.example_script: 'Only one person can win. And what happens next... none of them saw coming.'
structure.purpose: Winner NOT revealed until END—drives full watch completion

cut_speed.description: Variable: 2-3 second cuts during action, 5-8 second holds during emotional moments

music_and_sound.technique: Silence during emotional confessionals; ambient environmental sounds (rain, wind) for immersion; clock ticking for countdown pressure

retention_editing_rules: Tease upcoming drama after each elimination
Never show final winner until last 2 minutes

the_turn.placement_description: Multiple smaller turns; major turn at 50-70% mark

turn_types.name: Alliance Betrayal
turn_types.description: Contestants team up then betray each other
turn_types.example: Two players make a secret deal, then one breaks it

turn_types.name: Rules Change
turn_types.description: New challenge introduced mid-competition
turn_types.example: 'Starting now, you can steal money from other players'

turn_types.name: The Dark Moment
turn_types.description: Someone almost gives up, emotional breakdown
turn_types.example: Front-runner has mental breakdown, considers quitting

turn_types.name: Underdog Rise
turn_types.description: Person expected to fail starts winning
turn_types.example: Weakest-looking contestant becomes dominant

the_turn.tension_mechanics: Investment in specific contestants; physical/emotional stakes visible; escalating difficulty over time

faceless_adaptability.notes: Excellent for faceless channels. Requires voiceover, stock footage, motion graphics. No on-camera presence needed. Perfect for AI-assisted production.

top_creators.name: MagnatesMedia
top_creators.role: Pioneer of cinematic business documentary format

psychological_mechanics.explanation: Pleasure derived from witnessing the fall of titans. Narrative follows Rise and Fall arc—viewers compelled by 'How did they lose it all?' This taps into deep human curiosity about hubris and failure. Information asymmetry (the 'secret' reason) keeps viewers engaged as they gain privileged knowledge.

rules: Year range adds credibility and scope
Numbers (revenue, valuation, year range) add specificity
examples: The Tragic Downfall of Blockbuster
How WeWork Lost $47 Billion
The Rise and Fall of Toys R Us (1948-2018)
The Impossible Collapse of FTX

thumbnail_meta.composition: Monochrome CEO portrait + Destroyed/cracked logo + Downward graph
thumbnail_meta.color_scheme: Desaturated with red/orange warning accents; heavy vignette
thumbnail_meta.text_overlays: Bold Impact or Bebas-style font with year ranges; downward arrows

structure.instruction: Show the devastating outcome FIRST (bankruptcy, jail, death, empty stores)
structure.example_script: [SLOW PAN across empty warehouse] 'It was supposed to be the future of retail. Worth $47 billion. Today, it's worth nothing.'

structure.instruction: Rapid montage of entity at peak—news clips praising them, stock soaring, celebrations
structure.example_script: [NEWS CLIPS] 'Revolutionary!' 'The next Amazon!' [STOCK CHART rising] [CHAMPAGNE popping]
structure.purpose: Show what was lost, maximize fall distance

structure.instruction: Explicitly state the central mystery
structure.example_script: 'So how did a company with $47 billion in funding... lose it all in just 18 months?'
structure.purpose: Frame the narrative question that drives watch time

structure.instruction: Kinetic title card with sound design. Signal documentary structure.
structure.example_script: [BASS DROP] [TEXT SLAMS ON SCREEN] 'PART ONE: THE VISION' [Dramatic score begins]
structure.purpose: Establish premium production value, set expectations

cut_speed.description: Medium-slow, audio-driven. Cuts occur on the beat of dramatic scores.

music_and_sound.music_style: Hans Zimmer-style dramatic tension, slow synthwave, deep bass rumbles
music_and_sound.technique: Music stops completely before major revelations for impact
music_and_sound.sound_effects: Bass drops on statistics, metallic hits on text slams, room tone for tension

visual_effects: Film burns and light leaks (vintage aesthetic)
retention_editing_rules: Recap key points before new chapters

turn_types.name: The Fatal Flaw
turn_types.description: Music stops. Narrator reveals the specific decision/event that doomed the entity.
turn_types.example: 'But they didn't account for one thing...' [SILENCE] '...the numbers were fake.'

turn_types.name: The Whistleblower
turn_types.description: Introduction of person who exposed the truth
turn_types.example: 'Then, one employee decided to speak up...'

turn_types.name: The Pattern
turn_types.description: Revealing that warning signs were always there
turn_types.example: 'Looking back, every disaster was predicted. They just didn't listen.'

the_turn.tension_mechanics: Build respect/awe for entity in first half; systematically dismantle in second half; regular 'But things were about to change...' transitions

algorithmic_implications.shareability: High—business cautionary tales get shared in professional networks

faceless_adaptability.notes: Traditionally requires on-location footage and host presence. Can be adapted with stock footage and maps, but loses authenticity. Hybrid approach possible with AI voiceover + licensed footage.

top_creators.name: PolyMatter
top_creators.role: Geopolitical analysis with clean motion graphics

psychological_mechanics.explanation: Physical travel = credibility. 'I went there' creates trust that armchair analysis cannot. The visual anchor technique (show visuals FIRST, context SECOND) reverses traditional journalism, creating immediate engagement before explanation. Viewers feel they're getting ground truth.

alternate_formulas: I Went to [Location] to Find Out the Truth
rules: Implies insider knowledge viewer doesn't have
examples: Why Russia is Invading Ukraine
The Secret Map of US Gangs
How Budget Airlines Actually Make Money
I Traveled to the Most Isolated Country on Earth

thumbnail_meta.face_expression: Host often not shown OR shown on-location in dramatic setting
thumbnail_meta.composition: Maps, geographic elements, national flags; documentary-style graphics; layered images
thumbnail_meta.color_scheme: Retro/vintage textures; sepia tones with pops of saturated color
thumbnail_meta.text_overlays: Question or provocative statement overlaid on map/location

structure.instruction: Jump straight into dramatic on-location footage or compelling visual
structure.example_script: [ON-LOCATION FOOTAGE] 'This is the most militarized border on Earth. And I'm standing right on it.'
structure.purpose: Immediate high-impact imagery within first 5 seconds

structure.instruction: Point camera at compelling visual evidence. Show before explaining.
structure.example_script: 'You can see it right here—' [POINTS AT MAP/OBJECT] '—this line is where everything changed.'

structure.instruction: Establish physical investment in the story
structure.example_script: 'I traveled 3,000 miles to find out the truth about what happened here.'

structure.instruction: Create anticipation for revelation that contradicts common belief
structure.example_script: 'What I discovered challenges everything you've been told about this conflict.'

structure.instruction: Briefly signal the story structure without spoiling
structure.example_script: 'The answer involves [Entity 1], [Entity 2], and a secret that goes back decades.'

hook_script.key_technique: Visual Anchor Before Contextual Bridge—show visuals FIRST, context SECOND (opposite of traditional journalism)

cut_speed.description: Alternates visual anchors → context bridges rhythmically throughout

b_roll_patterns: On-location documentary footage central to narrative
8-frame slide animations instead of continuous Ken Burns pan (Harris signature)
Expert interview clips as brief punctuation

music_and_sound.technique: Music follows emotional arc—tension during investigation, release during revelations

visual_effects: Film burns and Gaussian blur vignettes

turn_types.name: The Investigative Reveal
turn_types.description: Discovery that mainstream sources weren't mentioning
turn_types.example: 'But then I discovered something no news outlet was reporting...'

turn_types.name: The Geographic Pivot
turn_types.description: Travel to new location reveals different perspective
turn_types.example: 'Everything changed when I crossed to the other side of the border.'

turn_types.name: The Historical Context Bomb
turn_types.description: Overlooked historical element reframes entire narrative
turn_types.example: 'To understand this, we have to go back to a decision made in 1947...'

the_turn.tension_mechanics: Personal reflection on-location creates genuine stakes; 'I went there to see for myself' builds trust; visual evidence feels irrefutable

algorithmic_implications.shareability: Very High—educational content with perspective gets shared

faceless_adaptability.notes: Can be done faceless with green screen avatar or pure screen recordings. Evidence-heavy format works well with voiceover. The confrontation element is harder without a real host.

top_creators.name: Coffeezilla
top_creators.role: Pioneer of format; crypto and influencer scam investigations

psychological_mechanics.explanation: Viewer participates in moral crusade against 'Bad Actor'. Narrative structured as detective story—collecting clues (receipts) leading to inevitable confrontation. Satisfies desire for vindication and truth exposure. Viewer feels they're 'in on it' before the scammer gets caught.

title_syntax.primary_formula: I Investigated [Name/Scam] and It's Worse Than You Think
alternate_formulas: [Name] is a Fraud. Here's the Proof.
rules: Name recognition or scam type in title
'Worse than you think' implies deeper investigation
examples: I Investigated Logan Paul's CryptoZoo and It's Worse Than You Think
The Fake Guru Pandemic
Exposing Dan Lok: The $100M Con Man
I Bought Every Ad I Saw for 24 Hours

thumbnail_meta.face_expression: Creator looking skeptical/shocked; scammer looking caught/smug
thumbnail_meta.composition: Creator vs. Scammer split; 'SCAM' stamp or lie in text bubble
key_elements: Before/after of scammer claims vs reality

structure.instruction: Play clip of target making bold, false claim
structure.example_script: [CLIP] Scammer: 'I made $10 million last month and you can too...'

structure.instruction: Creator enters frame or voiceover immediately contradicts
structure.example_script: 'This is [Name]. He claims [X]. But the truth is much darker. And I have the receipts.'

structure.instruction: Quantify the damage—money lost, people hurt
structure.example_script: 'Millions of dollars are missing. Hundreds of victims. And the man behind it all? He's still selling.'

structure.instruction: Promise the investigation structure
structure.example_script: 'In this video, we track the money, expose the network, and I confront the man himself.'

cut_speed.description: Medium-fast with heavy use of picture-in-picture reactions

b_roll_patterns: Screenshots of emails, DMs, blockchain transactions (highlighted)
Screen recordings of websites and courses

music_and_sound.technique: Buzzer or record scratch sound effect when lie is caught; dramatic pause before evidence reveal
music_and_sound.sound_effects: 8-bit sounds for comedic effect on obvious lies

visual_effects: Red circles and arrows on evidence
retention_editing_rules: Evidence hierarchy: small lies → big lies → smoking gun

turn_types.name: The Phone Call
turn_types.description: Creator finally gets scammer on the phone with evidence
turn_types.example: 'So I called him. And asked about the missing money directly.'

turn_types.name: The In-Person Visit
turn_types.description: Creator shows up at scammer's location
turn_types.example: 'I flew to Miami to ask him one question...'

turn_types.name: The Victim Testimony
turn_types.description: Real victims share their stories
turn_types.example: 'But the real story isn't the money. It's the people he destroyed.'

turn_types.name: The Paper Trail
turn_types.description: Final piece of evidence that proves everything
turn_types.example: 'And then I found this document. It changes everything.'

the_turn.tension_mechanics: Build evidence systematically; each piece worse than the last; confrontation is the payoff the entire video builds toward

algorithmic_implications.shareability: Very High—exposés get shared as warnings

faceless_adaptability.notes: Perfect for faceless channels. Voiceover over public domain interrogation footage. Minimal production needs. AI voiceover works well with the clinical tone required.

top_creators.name: Matt Orchard
top_creators.role: Crime and Society analysis, highest production heir

psychological_mechanics.explanation: Viewer placed in position of expert observer decoding 'Hidden Language' of human behavior. By explaining why a suspect touched their face or shifted in their chair, creator gives viewer sense of psychological insight. Satisfies human desire to spot liars and understand manipulation mechanics.

rules: Name of subject in title for searchability
Behavioral framing creates educational value proposition
examples: What Pretending to be Crazy Looks Like
The Case of Chris Watts
The Interrogation that Shocked Detectives
When the Killer's Story Falls Apart

thumbnail_meta.face_expression: Mugshot or interrogation room screenshot—distressed or smug suspect
thumbnail_meta.composition: Close-up of suspect's face; split showing 'mask slipping' between calm and distressed
thumbnail_meta.text_overlays: Minimal—suspect's name or specific behavioral tell
key_elements: Red circles pointing to body language cues

structure.instruction: Cold open on clip of suspect saying something odd or behaving strangely
structure.example_script: [INTERROGATION CLIP] Suspect: [Strange statement or laugh] [FREEZE FRAME]
structure.purpose: Immediate hook with highest-tension moment or weirdest behavior

structure.instruction: Dry, monotone narrator establishes crime and suspect
structure.example_script: 'This is [Name]. He has just been arrested for [Crime]. He believes he's smarter than the detectives. He's wrong.'
structure.purpose: Ground viewer in facts, establish clinical tone

structure.instruction: Signal what the viewer should watch for
structure.example_script: 'Watch closely how his story falls apart the moment the detective introduces [Evidence/Tactic]. Pay attention to his hands.'
structure.purpose: Give viewer framework—they now feel like an expert watching

hook_script.key_technique: 'Watch carefully. In the next few seconds, [Name] is going to make a critical mistake—one that trained interrogators are specifically watching for...'

cut_speed.description: Slow—long takes of interrogation footage allowed to breathe. Sped up during mundane sections, slowed for key moments.

b_roll_patterns: Raw interrogation footage as primary content
Freeze frames with red circles on body language cues
Tactical text overlays identifying techniques ('The Reid Technique', 'Minimization')
Minimal additional B-roll—footage speaks for itself

music_and_sound.music_style: Dark ambient, low drones, subtle tension builders
music_and_sound.technique: Silence used heavily—often long periods with only room tone; music only for transitions or builds

pacing_and_edit.voiceover_style: Dry, monotone, clinical delivery—'Voice of God' style (think Werner Herzog)
retention_editing_rules: 'Pause and Analyze' mechanic—play clip, pause, dissect
Build tension through annotation of interrogator tactics

turn_types.name: The Facade Break
turn_types.description: Moment suspect's mask slips—confession, caught in lie, psychological disintegration
turn_types.example: 'And here it is. The moment he realizes they know everything.'

turn_types.name: The Tactic Success
turn_types.description: Interrogator's strategy finally works after hours of pressure
turn_types.example: 'The detective has been building to this for three hours. Watch what happens when he plays the tape.'

turn_types.name: The Evidence Reveal
turn_types.description: Smoking gun evidence introduced that suspect didn't know existed
turn_types.example: 'But the detective has been holding something back. DNA from the scene.'

the_turn.tension_mechanics: Build-up through detailed annotation of interrogator tactics; payoff when tactics succeed; viewer feels they 'called it' because they were watching the tells

algorithmic_implications.shareability: Medium—niche but dedicated audience shares within communities
algorithmic_implications.note: Long-form dominates; algorithm rewards watch time heavily in this niche

faceless_adaptability.notes: Works well faceless with strong motion graphics and voiceover. Requires high-quality animation/visualization capabilities. Derek Muller style requires on-camera, but Mark Rober experiments can be adapted.

psychological_mechanics.explanation: Treats complex topics like detective stories. Opens with counterintuitive hook, creates knowledge gap (you don't know what you don't know), then delivers satisfying 'aha' revelation. Viewer feels smarter after watching. PhD-backed approach exposes flawed assumptions, creating emotional investment in correct answer.

rules: Avoid technical jargon (e.g., 'Magnus Effect' becomes 'Backspin Basketball')
35% CTR increase when using selective ALL CAPS words
examples: The Simplest Math Problem No One Can Solve
The Trillion Dollar Equation
How Gravity Actually Works
Most People Don't Know How Bikes Work

thumbnail_meta.face_expression: Curious/intrigued—eyebrow raised, slight open mouth; discovery moment
thumbnail_meta.composition: Scientific diagram integrated with dramatic imagery; something visually unexpected demanding explanation
thumbnail_meta.color_scheme: BOGY scheme (Blue, Orange, Green, Yellow)—high contrast colors that stop scrolls
thumbnail_meta.text_overlays: Minimal (1-3 words max), bold sans-serif; question marks
key_elements: Red circles/arrows pointing at key element

structure.instruction: Visual surprise or shocking statement that contradicts common belief
structure.example_script: 'This is the most contaminated river in America...' [DRAMATIC SHOT]
structure.purpose: 50-60% of drop-offs occur in first 3 seconds—must arrest attention

structure.instruction: Reveal the mystery—something viewer didn't know they didn't know
structure.example_script: '...and scientists couldn't figure out why until they discovered something hiding in plain sight.'

structure.instruction: Why this matters to the viewer personally
structure.example_script: 'What they found has implications for every person watching this video.'

structure.instruction: Signal expertise and research depth
structure.example_script: 'I spoke to three Nobel laureates and spent six months investigating...'
structure.purpose: Authority signals justify watch time investment

structure.instruction: Explicit roadmap of value
structure.example_script: 'By the end of this video, you'll understand something about physics that changes how you see the world.'

hook_script.key_technique: Treat science like a detective story—introduce puzzle, walk through wrong assumptions, then reveal 'aha' moment that feels earned
forbidden_elements: Starting with 'Today I'm going to explain...'

cut_speed.description: Scene changes every 5-8 seconds during explanation segments

b_roll_patterns: Data visualizations appearing within first 20 seconds
Mix of real-world demonstrations with motion graphics

music_and_sound.technique: Music swells during revelation moments; quieter during complex explanations

pacing_and_edit.animation_usage: Heavy—essential for visualizing invisible concepts; data viz critical for retention
retention_editing_rules: Regular 'But here's where it gets interesting...' hooks

turn_types.name: The Misconception Reveal
turn_types.description: Expose what viewers think they know is wrong
turn_types.example: 'Everything I just told you is what scientists believed for 50 years. They were wrong.'

turn_types.name: The Expert Contradiction
turn_types.description: Mainstream view vs contrarian evidence
turn_types.example: 'But when I asked Dr. [Name], she said something that changed everything...'

turn_types.name: The Demonstration Proof
turn_types.description: Visual experiment that proves the counterintuitive point
turn_types.example: 'So I built this experiment to prove it. Watch what happens...'

the_turn.tension_mechanics: Build up common belief, then systematically demolish it with evidence; viewers want to be 'in on the secret'

algorithmic_implications.shareability: Very High—'Did you know?' content drives social sharing

faceless_adaptability.notes: Perfect for faceless. Voiceover over custom graphics/archival footage. Campfire storytelling energy works with AI voice. Wendigoon-style is personality-driven but LEMMiNO-style is fully producible without face.

top_creators.name: LEMMiNO
top_creators.role: Polished mystery documentaries, highest production quality

psychological_mechanics.explanation: Creates sense of being pulled into self-contained world. Faceless narration allows viewer to project themselves into mystery. Iceberg format creates 'descent'—each layer darker/stranger than last. Tone is often eerie or melancholic, triggering awe that keeps viewer watching.

rules: Iceberg format signals depth of content
examples: Cicada 3301: An Internet Mystery
The Conspiracy Theory Iceberg
I Investigated YouTube's Strangest Channel
The Disturbing Reality of Local 58

thumbnail_meta.composition: Iceberg showing tiered layers OR single mysterious object against void
thumbnail_meta.color_scheme: Dark aesthetic—black backgrounds, muted colors with neon accents (green terminal text, red warnings)
thumbnail_meta.text_overlays: Question marks, '???', redacted text, glitch effects

structure.instruction: Present central enigma with atmospheric opening
structure.example_script: [EERIE MUSIC] 'In 2012, a puzzle appeared on the internet that would consume thousands of the world's most brilliant minds.'

structure.instruction: Demonstrate research depth
structure.example_script: 'I've spent the last six months researching this. What I found... I'm still not sure I believe.'

structure.instruction: Why this matters or why it's unsettling
structure.example_script: 'To this day, nobody knows who created it. Or why. But the theories... they get dark.'

structure.instruction: Signal structure (especially for iceberg format)
structure.example_script: 'We're going to go through this layer by layer. And by the end, you'll see why people are still obsessed.'

hook_script.key_technique: Eerie ambient music + mysterious imagery. 'This is the story of [Mystery].'

cut_speed.description: Variable—can be slow for atmosphere or faster during exposition

b_roll_patterns: Recreated interfaces and archived web pages
Glitch effects, VHS filters for 'found footage' feel

music_and_sound.music_style: Ambient, atmospheric, building tension—Blade Runner vibes
music_and_sound.technique: Custom or royalty-free 'dark ambient'; music gets progressively darker as content descends

visual_effects: Fluid transitions—scenes morph into one another
retention_editing_rules: Iceberg descent—each layer reveals something darker
Regular 'But here's where it gets really weird...' hooks

the_turn.placement_description: Around 70% mark, or multiple mini-revelations throughout

turn_types.name: The Descent Moment
turn_types.description: When 'normal' curiosity gives way to disturbing implications
turn_types.example: 'But then I found something. And honestly? I wish I hadn't.'

turn_types.name: The Real-World Connection
turn_types.description: Internet mystery connects to actual events/people
turn_types.example: 'The coordinates led to a real location. People went there. What they found...'

turn_types.name: The Perspective Shift
turn_types.description: Theory that recontextualizes everything viewer just learned
turn_types.example: 'But there is another possibility. What if the puzzle was never meant to be solved?'

turn_types.name: The Unsolved Acknowledgment
turn_types.description: Admitting what remains unknown
turn_types.example: 'To this day, no one knows the answer. And maybe we never will.'

the_turn.tension_mechanics: Iceberg descent—each layer reveals something darker; regular 'But here's where it gets really weird...' hooks; acknowledge increasing strangeness

algorithmic_implications.note: Wendigoon's icebergs often 3+ hours; algorithm rewards extreme watch time

faceless_adaptability.notes: Can be done faceless with high-quality product B-roll and voiceover. Loses the 'trusted face' element but works for pure product focus. Requires expensive camera equipment for 'product porn' aesthetic.

top_creators.name: MKBHD
top_creators.role: Gold standard for premium tech reviews

psychological_mechanics.explanation: Successful reviews frame product within a 'Paradox' (e.g., 'The Best Phone You Shouldn't Buy'). Cognitive dissonance hooks viewer, who watches to resolve contradiction. Creator acts as 'Trusted Authority' cutting through marketing hype. Viewer relies on parasocial relationship to make financial decisions.

examples: iPhone 16 Pro Max: 6 Months Later
The Worst Product I've Ever Reviewed
Galaxy S25 Ultra: The One to Get!
MacBook Pro M4: Don't Be Satisfied!

thumbnail_meta.face_expression: Neutral/confident when shown; face appears sparingly
thumbnail_meta.composition: Single product on solid/dark background; studio lighting; high-end product photography
thumbnail_meta.color_scheme: Natural/realistic—'no overdone filters'; dark backgrounds with product as hero
thumbnail_meta.text_overlays: Minimal (1-3 words max)—sometimes just checkmark or X

structure.instruction: Establish testing credibility through personal context
structure.example_script: 'I've been using this for six weeks now. Every single day. And I have thoughts.'

structure.instruction: Position as answering 'Is this worth YOUR money?'
structure.example_script: 'There's been a lot of hype around this phone. So let's break down what it actually delivers.'

structure.instruction: Hint at verdict to create narrative tension
structure.example_script: 'Spoiler: this might be my favorite [category] yet. OR There's a catch that almost killed it for me.'

structure.instruction: Set expectations for comprehensive coverage
structure.example_script: 'Let's break down everything you need to know. Display. Camera. Battery. And whether it's actually worth the price.'

hook_script.key_technique: 98% scripted dialogue—written in bold; B-roll cues unbolded

cut_speed.description: Clean jump cuts maintaining context between takes

b_roll_patterns: Product in real-world settings (outdoor shots, lifestyle contexts)
Macro detail shots showcasing build quality
J-cuts (audio leads video) for smooth transitions

production_requirements.software: DaVinci Resolve, Final Cut Pro with MotionVFX plugins
production_requirements.lighting: Professional studio lighting for product shots

turn_types.name: The BUT Moment
turn_types.description: Pivot from praise to criticism (or vice versa)
turn_types.example: 'The hardware is perfect... BUT the software ruins it.'

turn_types.name: The Unexpected Finding
turn_types.description: Surprising test result that changes assessment
turn_types.example: 'But when I tested real-world battery life, something weird happened.'

turn_types.name: The Use-Case Split
turn_types.description: Verdict depends on viewer type
turn_types.example: 'If you're X type of user, yes. If you're Y, wait for next year.'

the_turn.tension_mechanics: Build positive momentum then introduce qualification; clear final verdict with context

algorithmic_implications.note: Often performs as evergreen content with search traffic

faceless_adaptability.notes: Can be done faceless with split-screen product footage and voiceover. Requires owning both products and consistent test conditions. Running score graphics essential.

top_creators.name: Mrwhosetheboss
top_creators.role: UK's largest tech YouTuber, comparison specialist

psychological_mechanics.explanation: Viewers often already own one product—they watch to validate their choice or find ammunition for arguments. Addresses both 'sides' of audience while delivering clear verdict. Running score format gamifies decision-making, making abstract comparisons tangible and satisfying.

alternate_formulas: [Product A] vs [Product B] - Which Should You Buy?
I Switched from [A] to [B] for [Time Period]
rules: Both products named for dual-audience searchability
examples: iPhone 16 Pro vs Galaxy S25 Ultra: The TRUTH
I Switched to Android After 10 Years
MacBook Pro vs Dell XPS: Which Should You Buy?
Camera Shootout: iPhone vs Pixel vs Samsung

thumbnail_meta.face_expression: Host in center (optional)—pointing to preferred choice or showing surprise
thumbnail_meta.composition: Split-screen design—Product A on left, Product B on right; both at matching angles
thumbnail_meta.color_scheme: Color coding for Team A vs Team B (blue vs orange common)
thumbnail_meta.text_overlays: VS/Battle graphics, lightning bolts, winner indicators (crown, checkmark)

structure.instruction: Establish testing credibility through personal ownership
structure.example_script: 'I've been using BOTH of these phones for the last two months. Every single day. Here's what I found.'

structure.instruction: Appeal to both audiences; reject fanboy framing
structure.example_script: 'Everyone's debating which one is actually better. The fanboys on both sides are wrong. The truth is more nuanced.'

structure.instruction: Build anticipation for verdict
structure.example_script: 'By the end of this video, you'll know exactly which one to buy. And there IS a clear winner.'

structure.instruction: Signal comprehensive test structure
structure.example_script: 'We're testing camera, display, performance, battery, and value. Let's get into it.'

hook_script.key_technique: 'As someone who's tested hundreds of phones...'—establish neutrality through volume of experience

cut_speed.description: Medium pace with clear section breaks

b_roll_patterns: Side-by-side test footage—same task on both devices

music_and_sound.technique: Music shifts to signal section changes; sound effects for score reveals

pacing_and_edit.category_structure: Camera → Display → Performance → Battery → Value (with timestamps/chapters)

the_turn.placement_description: Often mid-video when unexpected category winner revealed

turn_types.name: The Category Flip
turn_types.description: Expected winner loses a category
turn_types.example: 'I was SURE the iPhone would win camera. I was wrong.'

turn_types.name: The Personal Use Revelation
turn_types.description: Creator reveals which they actually use daily
turn_types.example: 'After all these tests, here's the one I've been reaching for every morning.'

turn_types.name: The Nuanced Verdict
turn_types.description: Winner depends on use case
turn_types.example: 'If you care about X, get A. If you care about Y, get B. Here's why...'

the_turn.tension_mechanics: Acknowledge both audiences; unexpected findings create discussion/comments; final verdict clear but contextualized

algorithmic_implications.shareability: Very High—shared in debates between product camps

faceless_adaptability.notes: Requires human attempting and failing at skills on camera. Core appeal is watching the struggle. Very difficult to make faceless without losing authenticity.

psychological_mechanics.explanation: Condensed Hero's Journey. Viewer identifies with creator's initial incompetence ('The Struggle Phase'). Witnessing repeated failure builds empathy. Eventual success triggers dopamine hit—viewer experiences 'Vicarious Achievement'. Validates idea that hard work leads to mastery.

alternate_formulas: I Trained [Skill] for [Hours/Days] - Here's What Happened
rules: Achievement must seem difficult but not impossible
examples: I Learned to Solve a Rubik's Cube in 24 Hours
30 Days to Run a Sub-20 5K
Can I Play Piano in 7 Days?
I Trained Like a Navy SEAL for 30 Days

thumbnail_meta.face_expression: Split: Frustrated/failing on left, triumphant/succeeding on right
thumbnail_meta.composition: Before/after split screen or chaos-to-mastery progression
thumbnail_meta.color_scheme: Contrasting—chaotic/dark on fail side, bright/clean on success side
thumbnail_meta.text_overlays: Timer graphic, day counter, skill name

structure.instruction: Show a pro doing the skill perfectly—establish the goal
structure.example_script: [PRO FOOTAGE] 'This looks impossible.' [SLOW MOTION of complex skill]

structure.instruction: Creator tries and fails miserably—comedic timing
structure.example_script: [CRASH/FAIL] 'I have no idea what I'm doing.' [FRUSTRATED REACTION]

structure.instruction: State the time constraint and stakes
structure.example_script: 'I have exactly 7 days to master this. If I fail, I have to [Consequence].'

structure.instruction: Immediate training montage—no more setup
structure.example_script: [TIMER STARTS] [TRAINING MONTAGE BEGINS]

hook_script.key_technique: The timer is always visible—quantitative progress creates narrative

b_roll_patterns: Failure supercuts set to comedic music

music_and_sound.music_style: Lo-fi hip hop for study/grind, upbeat rock for success moments
music_and_sound.technique: Music shifts with emotional arc—frustration, persistence, triumph

retention_editing_rules: Failure Supercut—rapid cuts of mistakes synced to music

turn_types.name: The Plateau
turn_types.description: Progress stops; creator considers giving up
turn_types.example: 'Day 4. I'm not getting any better. I don't know if I can do this.'

turn_types.name: The Technique Discovery
turn_types.description: Creator finds 'secret' technique that unlocks progress
turn_types.example: 'Then I found this one tip that changed everything...'

turn_types.name: The Breakthrough Moment
turn_types.description: First successful completion after many failures
turn_types.example: [SLOW MOTION] 'Wait... DID I JUST DO IT?!'

the_turn.tension_mechanics: Investment through watching struggle; payoff of eventual success; timer creates urgency throughout

faceless_adaptability.notes: Requires real human participants, studio setup, and social interaction. Cannot be made faceless. Core appeal is watching real human reactions and judgment.

top_creators.name: Jubilee
top_creators.role: Pioneer of format (Middle Ground, Odd One Out)

top_creators.name: Sidemen
top_creators.role: UK group social games and challenges

psychological_mechanics.explanation: Viewer instinctively picks sides or favorites. Heavy use of 'Cringe'—watching people behave under social pressure. The 'Button' mechanic (Cut) externalizes internal rejection, making emotional stakes visible and instantaneous. Gamified human interaction satisfies judgment impulse.

rules: Conflict or judgment implied in title
examples: 20 Women vs 1 Sideman: Speed Dating
Millennial vs Gen Z: What's the Difference?
6 Vegans vs 1 Meat Eater
Can 100 Teens Spot the Fake Gen Z?

thumbnail_meta.composition: Two opposing groups staring at each other OR one person surrounded by many

structure.instruction: Montage of the most shocking/awkward/angry moments from the video
structure.example_script: [RAPID CUTS] Gasps, shocked faces, dramatic moments, someone saying something controversial

structure.instruction: Simple, clear game mechanics
structure.example_script: 'We brought 6 strangers together. One is a millionaire, the rest are broke. Can they spot the liar?'

structure.instruction: Game begins immediately—first question asked
structure.example_script: [PARTICIPANTS SIT] 'Round 1. Introduce yourself and tell us what you do for a living.'

hook_script.key_technique: The Button/Elimination mechanic makes internal judgment visible and instantaneous

cut_speed.description: Reaction-heavy—cuts focus on listener's face to show judgment

music_and_sound.music_style: Pizzicato strings (for awkwardness), tense drones (for conflict)
music_and_sound.technique: Sound effects on button presses; silence before dramatic moments

visual_effects: Subtitles highlighting stuttering, pauses, specific phrases
pacing_and_edit.studio_requirement: White void/cyclorama—featureless studio keeps focus on faces
retention_editing_rules: Reaction shots of listener's face during speaker

the_turn.placement_description: Multiple turns—each elimination is a mini-turn

turn_types.name: The Elimination
turn_types.description: Player voted out—dramatic button press or vote reveal
turn_types.example: 'The group has spoken. [Name], your button is red.'

turn_types.name: The Secret Reveal
turn_types.description: Hidden role or truth revealed
turn_types.example: 'Actually... I AM the millionaire.'

turn_types.name: The Conflict Escalation
turn_types.description: Two participants clash over belief or statement
turn_types.example: 'Wait, you actually believe that? Let me explain why you're wrong.'

the_turn.tension_mechanics: Social friction is the content; judgment is the mechanic; reveals are the payoffs

algorithmic_implications.shareability: Very High—clips go viral on TikTok and Shorts

faceless_adaptability.notes: Can be partially adapted with B-roll lifestyle footage and voiceover. Loses personal connection but aesthetic is producible. Works better with consistent on-camera presence for relatability.

top_creators.name: Ali Abdaal
top_creators.role: Productivity system reviews, doctor turned creator

psychological_mechanics.explanation: Balances 'Aspiration' (the aesthetic, productive life viewer wants) with 'Relatability' (the struggle to maintain it). Creator admits to burnout or procrastination, making eventual solution ('The System') feel attainable. Appeals to desire for self-improvement and control over environment.

alternate_formulas: What Happened When I [Habit] Every Day for a Month
rules: Method must be testable and trendy
examples: I Tried Waking Up at 5AM for 30 Days
I Followed Tim Ferriss's Morning Routine
30 Days of Meditation - What I Learned
I Deleted Social Media for a Month

thumbnail_meta.face_expression: Before/After split—tired vs. happy OR surrounded by specific tools
thumbnail_meta.composition: Clean, minimalist aesthetic; creator in productivity-coded environment
thumbnail_meta.color_scheme: Warm, inviting; soft lighting; earth tones

structure.instruction: Establish relatable struggle—the problem to solve
structure.example_script: 'I felt burnt out. I couldn't focus on anything for more than 10 minutes. Sound familiar?'

structure.instruction: Introduce the method being tested with authority hook
structure.example_script: 'Then I discovered this method used by Navy SEALs and Silicon Valley CEOs. It sounded too good to be true.'

structure.instruction: State the experiment parameters clearly
structure.example_script: 'For the next 30 days, I'm going to follow this exactly. No cheating. Here are the rules.'

hook_script.key_technique: Treat life as a system to be optimized—scientific framing of personal development

cut_speed.description: Calm—L-cuts used to blend dialogue smoothly

b_roll_patterns: Cinematic vlog style—slow motion coffee pouring, typing, walking

music_and_sound.music_style: Lo-fi beats, acoustic guitar, soft piano

pacing_and_edit.aesthetic: Productivity Chic—clean desks, plants, warm lighting, organized bookshelves

turn_types.name: The Struggle
turn_types.description: Novelty wears off; habit becomes difficult
turn_types.example: 'Day 12. I hate this. The excitement is gone and this just feels like work.'

turn_types.name: The Adaptation
turn_types.description: Creator modifies method to make it sustainable
turn_types.example: 'So I made one change. And everything clicked.'

turn_types.name: The Insight
turn_types.description: Unexpected lesson beyond the surface habit
turn_types.example: 'But the real lesson wasn't about waking up early. It was about...'

the_turn.tension_mechanics: Show reality behind the aesthetic; honest struggle builds trust; system revelation is the payoff

algorithmic_implications.shareability: High—practical content gets saved and shared

faceless_adaptability.notes: Cannot be made faceless. Entire format requires authentic human vulnerability on camera. The raw, de-produced aesthetic is the point. AI/faceless would defeat purpose.

top_creators.name: Any Creator Pivoting
top_creators.role: Format used by established creators during transitions

top_creators.name: Lifestyle/Vlog Creators
top_creators.role: Common in beauty, lifestyle, and daily vlog spaces

psychological_mechanics.explanation: Viewer, accustomed to high-energy entertainment, is arrested by sudden shift to raw vulnerability. Triggers 'Rescue Fantasy'—viewer wants to support creator. Also serves as 'Pattern Interrupt' in algorithm—slow, sad video amidst sea of loud, fast content stands out.

alternate_formulas: I Need to Be Honest With You
The Truth About Why I Disappeared
rules: Title must be short and stark
Period instead of ellipsis or exclamation
examples: I Quit.
The Truth.
I'm Taking a Break.
This Needs to Stop.

thumbnail_meta.face_expression: Sad/tired—no makeup, natural lighting, genuine exhaustion
thumbnail_meta.composition: Just face, no props, no background emphasis
thumbnail_meta.color_scheme: Low contrast; sometimes black and white; desaturated
thumbnail_meta.text_overlays: None or minimal—title does the work

structure.instruction: Creator sighs, looks down, adjusts camera. Long pause before speaking.
structure.example_script: [SIGH] [LOOKS DOWN] [ADJUSTS CAMERA] '...I didn't want to make this video.'
structure.purpose: Signal this is different—authenticity through discomfort

structure.instruction: Simple, honest statement of what's wrong
structure.example_script: 'For the last year, I haven't been honest with you. Or with myself. And I need to talk about it.'
structure.purpose: Break fourth wall of curated content

hook_script.key_technique: Deliberate de-production—the rawness IS the message

cut_speed.description: Raw—jump cuts kept in (to show 'realness') or long unedited takes

b_roll_patterns: If any B-roll: behind-the-scenes showing stress

music_and_sound.music_style: Silence or very minimal sad piano
music_and_sound.technique: NO background music during core confession—silence is the point

visual_effects: Possibly timestamps if video is very long
pacing_and_edit.aesthetic: Deliberately 'De-Produced'—no fancy lighting, often handheld, sitting on floor
retention_editing_rules: Long pauses and sighs kept in

turn_types.name: The Hope Statement
turn_types.description: After vulnerability, creator shares path forward
turn_types.example: 'I'm not leaving forever. But things have to change. Here's what I'm going to do differently.'

turn_types.name: The New Direction
turn_types.description: Announce content pivot or schedule change
turn_types.example: 'From now on, I'm only posting when I have something meaningful to say.'

turn_types.name: The Gratitude Close
turn_types.description: Thank audience for support through tough time
turn_types.example: 'Thank you for being here. I mean that. See you soon.'

the_turn.tension_mechanics: Despair → Explanation → Hope. The turn from darkness to light provides emotional release.

algorithmic_implications.note: Often performs differently than normal content—high engagement, lower views, but renews audience connection

hook_timing_rules.3_second_rule: 50-60% of drop-offs occur in first 3 seconds
hook_timing_rules.60_second_contract: Viewer should know exactly what they're getting and why they should stay

tier_1_excellent.notes: Voiceover + existing footage/graphics. Perfect for AI-assisted production.

tier_2_adaptable.notes: Can work faceless but loses some engagement. Requires high-quality assets.

tier_3_difficult.notes: Requires human on camera for core appeal.

tier_4_impossible.notes: Cannot be made faceless. Human interaction/vulnerability is the content.

content_classification.instruction: When classifying existing content, score against all 14 archetypes using hook_script structure match, pacing analysis, and turn placement detection. Primary archetype = highest score. Note hybrid archetypes.
hybrid_examples: The Fraud Gauntlet (Fraud Hunter + Survival elements)

content_generation.instruction: When generating content, select archetype based on: (1) subject matter fit, (2) production capability, (3) faceless adaptability score if applicable. Follow hook_script timestamps exactly. Implement turn at specified percentage.
mandatory_elements: First 3 seconds must match thumbnail promise

title_thumbnail_generation.instruction: Use title_syntax formulas and thumbnail_meta specifications exactly. Test multiple variations against archetype examples. Ensure title-thumbnail-hook alignment—all three must promise the same thing.
